title: Collective Semantics: Collective Intelligence & the Semantic Web - Use of multiple background ontologies in ontology matching
segmentation: Thank you very much.
So good afternoon everyone.
I come from Philips Research.
I'm going to talk about ontology matching.
And the title of my talk is use of multiple parent ontologies in ontology matching.
So I structured my talking four parts.
I will do my best to keep it as short as possible to have more discussion in the end.
So first I will talk about I will introduce the problem of ontology matching.
I will talk about the approach that we take.
So how do we use background knowledge?
My study here is very experimental, so I will explain the case study that we did the experimental setup.
The data that we used.
I will explain the result.
How do we interpret these results and what does it eventually mean for Don teologi matching and how is it important for the collective semantics?
So ontology matching is one of the central subjects in the semantic web.
Solutions are necessary in many applications since we're on a semantic web conference, I'm not going to spend too much time on explaining why it is important.
I guess everyone knows already.
For ontology matching, there are many divisions, many classifications, so the available approaches.
How can they be clustered classified?
We adopt one classification from 2004 which classifieds all the approaches in lexical techniques, structural instance based and using background touch.
In the paper where we get it from, it's called little bit slightly different, so like semantic approach, but it's basically that's it, so using background knowledge.
So as I said, we focus on the idea of using background knowledge to solve this problem or photology match.
The way we performed using background knowledge, it proceeds in two steps.

The first step is anchoring, so we have the matching ontologist we want to attach them to the background technology and in the second step we want to derive the actual matches by using this bridge that we have established and by using the structure of the background knowledge.
So here is the scheme.
How it looks like this process?
So the first the source and the target ontology are anchored to the background knowledge, and then we use the background image.
Is the image already suggests.
We expect that the background knowledge is something large, so it can provide some additional knowledge that's not contained in the source in the target.
To the this idea with an example, this is just a very simple example.
We have in the Source Ontology concept that's called brain.
In the target concept, that's called head.
So using background knowledge here helps.
By first lexical matching the source and the target concepts to the background knowledge and we see here they are related so we can derive indirect match that brain is nearer than head.
This is a realistic example actually cause brain usually in all the classifications that exist online.
It's just classified under the central nervous system.
So it's not really connected to head and like this by using some more comprehensive background knowledge we can find the link which is very useful.
OK, so using background knowledge it seems like a nice idea, but actually work in practice.
To check that we conducted the case study.
Where we matched to ontologies.
Not onagra book.
They were extracted from the ontology Alignment Evaluation Initiative from the 2005.
Data.
And we match this to Ontologist first with the direct matching.
I will explain that one.
It's a very simple matching that we did there.
And we also conducted 6 further experiments to use background knowledge.
So in each experiment with one ontology as a background knowledge.
And afterwards we did investigation.
OK well this means to use this multiple intelligences at the same time to solve the problem.
The background knowledge was extracted from online.
It was six ontologies and we did our best actually to cover different types of ontologies that we managed to find online.
So the first ontology it is a different domain ontology.
So these are agricultural disorders is not a nag.
Revoke and economist covers the domain of economy.
But economies and ontology which was created by experts.
It's published online.
You can find references in the paper.
So where did we get it from?
The next three ontologies?
They were just general knowledge ontologies.
And finally, the last ontologies a.com and three.
These were.
Virtually from an unknown origin, we didn't manage to get the sources where they come from, but they were published online, so this kind of ontologist really exists on the semantic web.
As we can see, the don't ologist differ a lot.
They differ in the size and number of concepts.
They also differed in the structure that contains.
Some are more structured summer, less structured eh.com hit more or less.
Very weak structure.
The others were very highly hierarchical.
So in our experiments in the first experiment we did direct matching.
First we used a simple lexical technique to adjust to get like initial matching between the concepts from the two matching ontologies.
And what we did is like account for case sensitivity.
Eliminate stop words a the North and so on.
And like different word order, that's what we accounted basically for.
And also I think for plural forms.
So that was the lexical part.
And in the second part we used the structure on the intelligence to find further subsumption matchings between the matching ontology.
In the 2nd to the 7th experiment, what we did was anchor first lexically the matching ontologies, the source and target to each of the background collection tollages.
And then we use the structure of the background knowledge ontologies to derive the indirect matches.
It's a matching result.
We expected the equivalent rather than an error, then relations which are basically a simple hierarchical structure.
So the result?

The first approach that we took, the direct matching, which we used as a baseline to see how much did we gain from the using the background knowledge to compare this to it produced 6006 and a half thousand matches in total and the number of sexually compatible to this that were obtained at the Ontology alignment evaluation at 2005.
In the later experiments we got.
In total, in direct matches there.
2000 and 200, roughly, of which one and a half thousand were basically addition, so these were not found in the direct matching.
But here so the last column here is accumulative.
Cool activity the number of indirect and matches, so this is not just some of these matches, but some of them were overlapping.

Up if you count actually the the first columns, what you will see is that these numbers are very close, so the cumulative number of all the matches that were discovered in the sum of all the numbers were very close to one another, which means that very few overlapping matches were found, so more or less each ontology found many exclusive matches for that ontology particular.
However, these tables that I show in the previous number, they don't talk a lot about the the the.
Thickness of the matches.
So what happens with the precision and recall?
To do the evaluation in the direct matching.
Because there were 6000 concepts, 6000 matches.
What we did was a random sample approach.
We took 10% of the matches and we evaluated them.
The direct matching showed 100% precision, so it was a very rigid technique.
But in the end.
All dimensions were correct that were discovered.
And it's a reference task.
We took the task of documentary classification, so this is very subjective.
Some of the matches are arguable whether they are correct or not.
Whereas for the indirect matching we took the effort to evaluate all the matches manually, so we got quite diverse results.
The precision is so we can see, so these are the interesting ones.
The additional that we obtained further than the baseline.
So what we see clearly the loser ontologies are these which are unknown origin, and we analyzed where do these ontologies fail?
They contain a lot of mistakes.
So for example there are connections.
There are relations like water and waste gas and turbines.
Our impression was that basically they come from some kind of directory structure, which was straightforward put into an ontology that was just published online.
With the recall what we see, the recall is not increased a lot, so it's about 8%.
This tells us something that basically selecting ontologies just online and using them as a background knowledge.
You have to be careful how you do it and what do you expect from it.
There are other studies where carefully selected background knowledge ontologies have boosted, like for 300% the number of matches that were obtained, so they're equal, increase was.
About 300%.
To conclude, so as I said, what background knowledge is used in this approach?
That's very important.
You have to analyze it.
You have to be careful what you select.
And of course I mean you have to adjust your expectations accordingly.
What our case studies showed is that the recall increases monotonically, so more or less the more background knowledge you throw to the system, the better results you will get.
The recall will increase becausw they do not find many overlapping matches.

On the other hand, the precision depends on the quality of the background knowledge, so the high quality ontologists they still had varying precision, like 50% and above, but the mistakes there were caused by contextual mistakes.
So probably people already hit experience here.
One and told you can have one context in the other ontology.
Well, how does it relate afterwards?
The relations within the ontologies can be clashing.
We got matches like Meat is a product.
Well this is very arguable.
This really depends on the context and how are these classifications being used.
So that's on the on the border.
That's kind of mistake.
So regardless of the domain, finally, the expert created background knowledge, the different domain ontology, economy and general knowledge ontologies they hit the same cost of errors.
So it was either small mistakes or contextual problems.
Questions.
In your conclusion, said that the position created, the quality increases monotonically.
This strikes man bit counter intuitive if you experiments, it may be bad if I imagine that I take.
100 or a few $1000 GS and probably the number of matches that are not so exact increases and I can get circles and other artifacts.
Can actually decrease the quality of the culture of roofing.
Smoked happening.
This is true.
That's what we expect, but it's experimental, not confirmed.
So what will be interesting?
Actually, another studies to check this behavior?
How will the matching behave when we have 200 ontologies and we did it only with six ontologies.
Basically most of the ontologies that you find online.
They don't have lexical overlap.
You're not going to get any anchoring to this type of background knowledge.
So finally, you cannot really expect to have matching.
But that's reasonable expectation.
So what monotonically increased in our experiment is basically the recall, but the precision was varying.
So when we added unknown origin ontologists, it started dropping.
That was basically.
